Award.AwardTitle: High-pressure and Temperature Elasticity and Equation of State of Hydrous Phase
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hydrous phases are stabilized in the oceanic crust through constant interaction between the lithosphere and the overlying hydrosphere. These hydrous phases lock up substantial amounts of water and, over geological time scale, play a significant role in influencing the global sea-level. Subduction zones, which are major tectonic features, transport water into the Earth's interior. The efficiency of the transport of water and the extent of mantle hydration are intimately linked with the thermodynamic stability and thermoelasticity of hydrous phases. Since water has considerable effects on melting and on the elastic and transport properties of the Solid Earth, it is important to constrain the degree of mantle hydration.

This research attempts to put more accurate constraints on the transport of water into the Earth's interior and on mantle hydration. It will contribute to scientific understanding of the crystal structure, thermodynamics, equation of state, and elasticity of various hydrous phases that are likely to be stabilized in subduction zone settings. It will relate the energetics and thermoelasticity of hydrous phases with the following aspects: transport of water into the Earth's interior; extent of mantle hydration; observed low velocity layers; and large anisotropy in subduction zone settings. The research will be conducted by using a unique combination of experimental and theoretical methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Award "High-pressure and Temperature Elasticity and Equation of Hydrous Phase" was originally awarded to PI Mookherjee while he was a research scientist at Cornell University, in 2012. The award #1250477. PI investigated equation of state of hydrous phases using experiments and density functional theory. PI Also trained two undergraduate students who presented their research at the annual American Geophysical Union Fall meeting. One of them won outstanding student paper award as an undergraduate and currently she pursuing higher studies and is enrolled in "Graduate program" at Stanford University. In late 2015 PI moved to Florida State University as a tenure-track assistant professor and since then the award has supported PI's activity in building a Mineral Physics Research program at FSU. The award was transferred to FSU and a new award #1639552 was assigned. The award supported a post-doctoral scholar. PI and the post-doctoral scholar established a Resonant Ultrasonic Spectroscopic (RUS) facility at the Department of Earth, Ocean & Atmospheric Sciences. This facility was also augmented with high-temperature tube furnace to explore elasticity of minerals at conditions relevant to the Earth's interior. This also lead to the publication of a peer-reviewed research article where the method was tested on a perovskite mineral undergoing phase transition and associated changes in elastic properties. The article is published in Physical Review B (reference #13). The post-doctoral scholar has had a successful training and is currently employed in Apexanalytics as a Big-Data scientist. At FSU, the award also supported two high-school students from the Young Scholar program (YSP), an undergraduate student and a PhD student at the Earth Materials lab, Department of Earth, Ocean & Atmospheric Sciences, FSU. All of these students used RUS  to explore elasticity of mineral phases at high temperature.

Over the entire time span, the award has supported undergraduate students, high-school students, post-doctoral scholars and lead to numerous conference abstracts/presentation and thirteen peer-reviewed publications-
